title: Modeling with Diff Eq - Separation of Variables

content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. A medication is administered to a patient. The amount, in milligrams, of the medication in the patient at time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> hours is modeled by a function <math alttext="y equals, A of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> that satisfies the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to t, equals, the fraction with numerator 12 minus y, and denominator 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>12</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> hours, there are <math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> milligrams of the medication in the patient. (a) A portion of the slope field for the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to t, equals, the fraction with numerator 12 minus y, and denominator 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>12</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> is given below. Sketch the solution curve through the point <math alttext="with coordinates 0 comma 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. A medication is administered to a patient. The amount, in milligrams, of the medication in the patient at time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> hours is modeled by a function <math alttext="y equals, A of t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> that satisfies the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to t, equals, the fraction with numerator 12 minus y, and denominator 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>12</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> hours, there are <math alttext="0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> milligrams of the medication in the patient. (a) A portion of the slope field for the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to t, equals, the fraction with numerator 12 minus y, and denominator 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>12</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> is given below. Sketch the solution curve through the point <math alttext="with coordinates 0 comma 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Using correct units, interpret the statement <math alttext="the limit as t approaches infinity, of, A of t, equals 12" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>∞</mi></mrow></munder><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> in the context of this problem.

(c) Use separation of variables to find <math alttext="y equals A of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, the particular solution to the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to t, equals, the fraction with numerator 12 minus y, and denominator 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>12</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> with initial condition <math alttext="A of 0 equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) A different procedure is used to administer the medication to a second patient. The amount, in milligrams, of the medication in the second patient at time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> hours is modeled by a function <math alttext="y equals B of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>B</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> that satisfies the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to t, equals, 3 minus the fraction with numerator y, and denominator t plus 2, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>. At time <math alttext="t equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> hour, there are <math alttext="2.5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> milligrams of the medication in the second patient. Is the rate of change of the amount of medication in the second patient increasing or decreasing at time <math alttext="t equals 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Give a reason for your answer.

topic.text: 1.2: Defining Limits and Using Limit Notation

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the classification of a given expression (e.g., Use the chain rule to find the derivative of a composite function).
